Field Label:
Thank you for taking the time to complete this survey. Based on your answers, you are not eligible to participate in this evaluation. We appreciate your time.

More information about monkeypox virus and the monkeypox vaccine is available here:

Monkeypox | Poxvirus | CDC

You can also use the following tool to find a monkeypox vaccine near you:

Monkeypox Vaccine Locator · Monkeypox Vaccine Locator (mpoxvaxmap.org)

Please click "SUBMIT" to exit the survey.

This questionnaire asks about you and your health. Some questions may feel uncomfortable to answer, but your answers are important and will help us understand the risk of monkeypox and the effectiveness of the monkeypox vaccine. All of your responses will be kept private and confidential.

We anticipate that the survey will take 5-10 minutes to complete.

If you need to stop and return to the survey later, you may click "Save and Return Later," found at the bottom of the survey, at any time. You will see a Return Code on your screen; you MUST record this code to access the survey later. When you are ready to return to the survey, click the link you originally received via email or text. Look for the "Returning?" link at the top of the survey page to enter your return code. (PLEASE NOTE: If you select the option to email yourself a link to the survey, you will receive a link to a blank survey and you will lose all of your work so far. To avoid this, you MUST note the return code and use that to access the survey.)

Thank you for participating!

For the questions below, please think back to the 3-week period before you were told by a healthcare provider that you had monkeypox. The next set of questions refers to monkeypox exposures you may have had during that time period.

For the questions below, please think back to the 3-week period before your clinic visit on [clinic_date]. The next set of questions refers to monkeypox exposures you may have had during that time period.

During the 3 weeks before you were told by a healthcare provider that you had monkeypox, did you have close contact with someone who was diagnosed with monkeypox?

The close contact may have occurred after they were diagnosed or before their diagnosis, during the 3 weeks before they started developing monkeypox symptoms, such as a rash or skin lesions.

(Close contact includes intimate and non-intimate contact like sex, hugging, kissing, sharing food/utensils, sharing sheets or towels, or sharing a living space.)

During the 3 weeks before your clinic visit on [clinic_date], did you have close contact with someone who was diagnosed with monkeypox?

The close contact may have occurred after they were diagnosed or before their diagnosis, during the 3 weeks before they started developing monkeypox symptoms, such as a rash or skin lesions.

(Close contact includes intimate and non-intimate contact like sex, hugging, kissing, sharing food/utensils, sharing sheets or towels, or sharing a living space.)
During the close contact with someone who was diagnosed with monkeypox, what types of non-intimate activities did you engage in with that person? (Check all that apply.)
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 1, Provided in-home care to someone diagnosed with monkeypox | 2, Shared food, utensils, or dishes | 3, Shared towels, bedding, or clothing | 4, Shared drug equipment (e.g., needles, cookers, or bongs) | 5, Face-to-face contact (being within six feet of an unmasked person with monkeypox for more than three hours without wearing a mask) | 6, Other | 7, No non-intimate contact

This form will be filled out by site staff from the state or local health department case report forms and the immunization registry.


Case Definitions for monkeypox (MPX) infection

  • Confirmed Case: Demonstration of the presence of Monkeypox virus DNA by polymerase chain reaction testing or Next-Generation sequencing of a clinical specimen OR isolation of Monkeypox virus in culture from a clinical specimen
  • Probable Case: No suspicion of other recent Orthopoxvirus exposure (e.g., Vaccinia virus in ACAM2000 vaccination) AND demonstration of the presence of:
    • Orthopoxvirus DNA by polymerase chain reaction of a clinical specimen OR
    • Orthopoxvirus using immunohistochemical or electron microscopy testing methods OR
    • Demonstration of detectable levels of anti-orthopoxvirus IgM antibody during the period of 4 to 56 days after rash onset
